mixed community, which included the daughters

6144.text:

I do blame you a little bit for not telling

9657.text:
me before.
But, after all, it doesn't matter.

9660.text:
We should have had to keep apart, you see,
even if this had not been in your life."

9665.text:
"No, we shouldn't, Sue!
This is the only obstacle."

9668.text:
"You forget that I must have loved you, and
wanted to be your wife, even if there had

9674.text:
been no obstacle," said Sue, with a gentle
seriousness which did not reveal her mind.

9679.text:
"And then we are cousins, and it is bad for
cousins to marry.

9683.text:
And—I am engaged to somebody else.
As to our going on together as we were going,

9688.text:
in a sort of friendly way, the people round
us would have made it unable to continue.

9693.text:
Their views of the relations of man and woman
are limited, as is proved by their expelling

9698.text:
me from the school.
Their philosophy only recognizes relations

9701.text:
based on animal desire.
The wide field of strong attachment where

9706.text:
desire plays, at least, only a secondary part,
is ignored by them—the part of—who is

9711.text:
it?—Venus Urania."
Her being able to talk learnedly showed that

9716.text:
she was mistress of herself again; and before
they parted she had almost regained her vivacious

9721.text:
glance, her reciprocity of tone, her gay manner,
and her second-thought attitude of critical

9726.text:
largeness towards others of her age and sex.
He could speak more freely now.

9732.text:
"There were several reasons against my telling
you rashly.

9736.text:
One was what I have said; another, that it
was always impressed upon me that I ought

9741.text:
not to marry—that I belonged to an odd and
peculiar family—the wrong breed for marriage."

9748.text:
"Ah—who used to say that to you?"
"My great-aunt. She said it always ended badly

9756.text:
My father used to say the same to me!"
They stood possessed by the same thought,

9761.text:
ugly enough, even as an assumption: that a
union between them, had such been possible,

9766.text:
would have meant a terrible intensification
of unfitness—two bitters in one dish.

9771.text:
"Oh, but there can't be anything in it!" she
said with nervous lightness.

9776.text:
"Our family have been unlucky of late years
in choosing mates—that's all."

9781.text:
And then they pretended to persuade themselves
that all that had happened was of no consequence,

9786.text:
and that they could still be cousins and friends
and warm correspondents, and have happy genial

9792.text:
times when they met, even if they met less
frequently than before.

9796.text:
Their parting was in good friendship, and
yet Jude's last look into her eyes was tinged

9801.text:
with inquiry, for he felt that he did not
even now quite know her mind.
